READ_TEXT_2000053.ContentEN:
Act Ⅰ – Nocturne of the Swans

The tale opens during the reign of Yushino, third Grand Duke of Yashnia. Long before he inherited the title, Yushino was famed as a patron of the arts — immersed in painting, court verse, and letters. He maintained a grand troupe of dancers, each handpicked by the duke himself. Word of the troupe's brilliance spread so widely that nobles from both the Empire's capital and the Church's seat contrived to serve as envoys, if only to witness one performance in that seaside duchy.

Yet when our curtain rises, Yushino does not praise art or boast of his refined taste. Instead he broods over the bane of his sleepless nights: too many siblings. His father, the second Grand Duke, sired more than a hundred sons, and every one of those brothers now covets the throne of so small a state. Whenever Yushino closes his eyes, their faces float before him. He once tried counting them to lull himself to sleep, only to grow more agitated. On the tenth sleepless night, he made a decision.

He spent ever more time at banquets, drinking heavily in hope of a few hours' oblivion — meagre, but better than none.
When courtiers counselled restraint he waved them off, declaring: "If anything in this world can grant me rest — be it at a molten mountain's core, in a whirlpool at sea, or flickering on the rim of the sky — I shall possess it."

Thus, in the first year of his rule, from sunrise to moonset he held feast after feast, inviting his brothers to dine beside him. Pomegranate‑coloured wine never ceased to flow, nor did the dark veins in his bloodshot eyes fade. Beneath the crystal dome, youths in scarlet gauze danced the Swan Dance and sang without pause. Their floating sleeves swept across the nobles' cheeks, leaving them flushed — like clouds blushed by the sun before it sinks beneath the waves.
And each time, the Grand Duke would raise his goblet, wine running into his beard, his smile twisting into something grotesque. Then, catching his brothers in that hazy, entranced moment, he would murmur: "Would you care to bring one of these sweet-voiced swans home, dear brother?" And under the spell of wine and swirling dancers — who could refuse such largesse?

Thus a thousand swans flew out, one by one, into noble households.

Parsifal's Note:
In this sequence the ensemble dance is the centrepiece. Momiji appears here as one among many nameless swans. She must catch the audience's eye — but never so brightly as to break the unity of the dance. That balance is the true challenge.

READ_TEXT_2000054.ContentEN:
Act Ⅱ – Bloodred Meteor Shower

In the third year of Grand Duke Yushino's reign, nightly revels were no longer confined to his own palace. Every one of his noble brothers had fallen under the spell of Yashnia's sweet‑voiced， graceful swans. Their songs drifted beyond the high walls of noble mansions; even the ragged street children could hum a line or two.
To mark the third anniversary of his ascension, Yushino proposed that these long‑scattered swans be gathered at the celebration beneath the palace dome for a single chorus.
The courtiers urged caution. The dancers had not sung together in years, they warned; if their harmony faltered before so many guests, ridicule was certain.
But Yushino — half‑swallowed by his gilded throne — would not be swayed. In his mind, the voices of the swans and the pulse of his own heart were still one.

The celebration began as scheduled. Nobles filled the hall. The swan dancers reunited in the centre of the marble floor. Their faces betrayed no joy, no sorrow — for they were swans, trained to sway with the music, to shape their smiles to the tune.
At a single, crystal note from Yushino's favourite dancer, a thousand voices rose as one — clear and keen, like lightning splitting the sky. When the last chord fell away, silence descended — like the sea after a storm, so calm it seemed the revelry moments ago had been no more than a dream.
Yushino's brothers drifted into deep, sugared dreams. He watched, envying their peace. Since taking the crown he himself had never slept so soundly.

But tonight — beneath the bright moonlight — surely even he could find peace.

"Tatarnaga. Four hundred and ninety‑nine insults against the Grand Duke. Verdict: execution."
The voice from the throne was ice. One by one, Yushino pronounced the name of the noble who had scorned him most — and the long list of charges, meticulously recorded by the very swan dancer he had gifted Tatarnaga three years before.
The dancer who had long kept close company with Tatarnaga stepped forward, her serenity unchanged. A gauzy sleeve brushed the nobleman's cheek, just as on the night they first met. Then — a dull thud. His head, still wearing the soft curve of an intoxicated smile, parted from his body before fear could reach his eyes. It sailed cleanly through the air, trailing a fine red arc — a meteor of flesh and blood. Scarlet rain spattered down, staining the swans' pristine robes.
The night was young; the stars were already falling.

Yushino barely glanced at the carnage. He seized the hair of the courtier who had doubted the swans' unity and snarled: "Their loyalty has never broken pitch. Fool. Drink — and be as obedient as they are!"
Blood‑dark wine flooded the man's mouth and nose. He choked, certain he would drown.
Then — to his astonishment — Yushino's grip slackened. The Grand Duke sagged back, and a thunderous snore rolled through the marble hall.
Never had such a sound echoed in that palace, yet from that night onward it returned at the same hour every evening.


Parsifal's Note:
This scene calls for a solo. Traditionally, Momiji's sung by a soprano — but I've seen tenors pull it off brilliantly. I'd very much like to try it.

READ_TEXT_2000055.ContentEN:
Act Ⅲ – A Thousand Letters

"To my most revered, most tenderly pitied, most admired Grand Duke Yushino — you who once spent three sleepless years for the continuance of Yashnia.
This is the one thousand and first secret letter I have written to you — in loyalty, and in love. And as in every letter before, I write what I shall gladly write again, and again, and again:

I am forever your docile swan.
I am forever, forever yours.
Forever and ever and ever.

I imagine that, by the time you read this, a smile must have softened your weary face. One of the courtiers kneeling below your throne would stir at the sound of your laughter and ask what has pleased you so. You'd ignore him, drink half a glass of Hyperborean wine — if you drained it all, it would spill through your beard and stain your robe.
You'd sip while you read, deciding whether to finish the drink in peace... or smash it in rage.

Yes, I know you. Your face is etched into my heart and soul.

From the day you sent me to the Lady's estate, I began to write to you. A thousand letters, sealed with wax and entrusted to birds that knew the way to your hand. 
And each time I pressed the seal, I knew exactly what expression you would wear as you read.

Before the blood‑stained banquet where red meteors rained through the hall, you liked my letters.
Not just because I was your favourite swan, but because the Lady was unlike your other kin.
Though the other swans never spoke of it, I knew their noble patrons mocked you in whispers. That was why we were sent into their houses — to gather their sins behind a veil of dance.
But the Lady was not like them. She never uttered a word against you.
She said you were admirable — for banishing the brother who once mistreated her.
She said you were pitiable — for tossing and turning through the night over your nobles' crimes.
She said you were brilliant — for wrapping grand designs in feasts and song.

She spoke of other things, too: of Yashnia's moon, which she saw each night; of Hyperborea's snow, which she had never seen; of Elysium's flowers, which visited only in dreams.
But not once did she ask me to dance. Perhaps she had seen too many swan dances in your palace — or perhaps she had never known a real friend.
I was disheartened. Swans are born to dance — yet I was left to write, with quills plucked from my own wings.
And still, I hoped — that each time you opened one of those harmless little letters, the furrows on your brow would soften.
And perhaps that is why, on the night of that blood‑drenched banquet, she alone walked out beneath the echo of your thunderous snores.
I followed her out, as she stepped into the dawn. Her breath misted in the cold, her shoulders trembled — fear of you, or joy for your newfound peace? I could not tell. I only felt relief — that she had never once spoken ill of you. If she had, even had I disobeyed your order, the other swans would have torn her apart like ravens at your command.
From that day on, I was the only swan who never returned to your palace.
Outwardly, nothing changed: she still shared her stories and wishes for travels with me, and every fourth day I sent you another letter.
But perhaps... it only seemed that way. Before the sun rises, all is called night. But the midnight of your thunderous snores, and the final breath before dawn — can they truly be the same?

Since then, I imagine you no longer smile when you read me.
You buried yourself in state affairs: reforms, punishments, suspicion. You trusted no one in Yashnia who still breathed. Even birdsong was questioned — for daring to disturb your sleep.
The Lady was no exception. Her praise became flattery. Her silence, a hidden slight. Her advice, betrayal.
How could you?

Allow me to be plain: from my first autumn in her estate, she let me stop calling myself "swan."
By now I expect you have hurled your wineglass in rage, Grand Duke Yushino.
You saved me from starvation — made me your ever-dancing swan. But she is the one who taught that swan to be a person.
She never asked me to dance — because people are not swans.
To protect her, I was ever obedient, ever gentle, ever yours. Always fearing your fury would fall on her.
But your suspicion grew like mould in the dark. I defended her, again and again. Until seven days ago — when you summoned her to the palace... and she never returned.
So now, I ask just one thing:

Is she still alive?

I no longer wish to be anyone's swan. If she is gone, then I shall tread upon the shards of your shattered glass — even if my feet must bleed to reach you — until your blood spills like wine and dyes your robe crimson.
By the time you reach this line, I will already be standing before you, ready to pierce this letter — and your throat — with the very same blade."

"Raise your head and answer me, Yushino!"


Parsifal's Note:
Except for the final line, the entire scene is sung by Yushino as he reads Momiji's letter aloud. The performance must reflect the full emotional arc within the letter — from deferential restraint, to repressed grief, to seething fury. The true challenge lies in moving seamlessly and convincingly between Yushino's visible reactions and the inner voice of Momiji, gradually rising to its breaking point. It demands exceptional control.

READ_TEXT_2000056.ContentEN:
Act Ⅳ – A Speck of Crimson

"That was only an acci—"
The Lady's death might indeed have been an accident. But even a swan knows: without Grand Duke Yushino's command, no gaoler would dare fetch the tools of torture.
And of all people, the limping figure now standing before him knew Yushino best — and hated him most.

So before he could finish the sentence, she drove her sword straight through his skull.

The tip of the blade first reached his tongue — a soft, writhing strip of flesh that split in two, bright red. It reminded her of a serpent's tongue. The Lady had once said she feared nothing more than the eight-headed serpent from Yashnia's ancient myths.
Then came something firmer — the upper palate. Heavy drinkers often complained of a burning sensation there. Yushino had drunk often, and well. Maybe his was tougher than most. Or maybe not — the steel passed through without resistance.
After that, everything was easy: the hindbrain. Some say it governs sleep. Years ago, Yushino scoured the land for physicians to cure his insomnia. One had told him the problem lay in his hindbrain. She no longer remembered whether that poor man had ended up with his skull smashed or his tongue cut out. Now, Yushino had suffered both. A shattered skull and a severed tongue — quite a poetic ending for him, right?
Before his bloodied lips could kiss the edge of her blade, she pulled it free.
A spray of scarlet spattered a folding screen; the fabric drank it in, the stain blooming like red leaves.

She remembered the day the Lady told her she no longer needed to call herself a swan.

It was an autumn afternoon, just before the frost set in. A northern wind from Hyperborea had swept away the last warmth lingering over Yashnia — only to spend all its strength in doing so. The sea turned bitter‑cold overnight. No nobles dared swim; no fishermen dared cast their nets.
Further inland, the farmers had just finished harvesting the wheat, yet still fretted that rain might come too soon and spoil the drying grain. Children, sent out reluctantly at the adults' urging, were tasked with picking up the fallen stalks — only to end up bickering over trifles halfway through. From the houses by the fields came the warm scent of fresh bread, baked with the season's first wheat. Cooking smoke curled gently from the chimneys.
Through that smoke flew the migratory birds bound south — save one small bird, a ribbon tied to its leg, winging the opposite way. It slipped through the domes and rooftops to deliver the four hundredth secret letter to Grand Duke Yushino.
It was his first year on the throne. Amidst sleepless nights, he had only just begun his long campaign — to purge his enemies and secure his rule. Perhaps the gods who govern the seasons took pity on his resolve and granted Yashnia another golden harvest.
And in that hush of ripened wheat, not far from the palace, in a quiet courtyard — a swan said no.

A cold wind stirred. The trees in the Lady's courtyard groaned softly, as if in pain. Red leaves drifted down like blood. One struck the Lady's face. She flinched with a startled yelp — like a cat caught by sudden darkness. The limping one reached out and gently brushed the leaf away.
The Lady's cheeks were flushed from the cold. She looked at her and said: "From now on, you don't have to call yourself a swan. Your name... will be Momiji. Only I will know this. Only I may call you this."

The swan hesitated. She agreed to stop calling herself a bird — but cautiously declined the name Momiji, afraid that if she heard it too often,
she might come to love it. And along with it... too many other things.

She could no longer recall what happened next. Only that, somehow, she had cried — though she never knew quite why.
Tears are warm at first. But they soon turn cold. And so do the red leaves — fiery in hue, cold in the hand.

Cold, like Yushino's blood already congealing on marble.

Perhaps it was because she hadn't danced in so long. She might have avoided the spatter, yet one drop landed on the hilt of her sword.
She tried to wipe the red away — again and again. But it wouldn't come off. And that brought her back to the moment when a red leaf had fallen onto the Lady's face. She had tried to brush it away, too — but hadn't been able to. As if she were waiting for someone else to do it for her.
She lingered again in that autumn, seven years ago — where everything had seemed well.
So be it, then. Let that speck of crimson remain.
She made no further attempt to wipe the blood away. Nor did she shy from the name Momiji any longer. She turned and walked away — unchallenged, and alone.

Thus closed the tale of Momiji: A Chronicle of Rebellion.


Parsifal's Note:
The protagonist's name — Momiji — isn't revealed until the very final act. When the play first debuted, this twist had tremendous impact. But now, after so many stagings, most audiences know it going in. It's a shame — there's nothing quite like the first time.
Here's an excerpt from the historical record. Might be useful...
"According to official chronicles, the third Grand Duke of Yashnia, Yushino, reigned for ten years. In the early years, he purged his political enemies and swept away many of the entrenched ills left by his predecessor, the second Grand Duke. But toward the end of his rule, he grew increasingly suspicious of his own kin. Eventually, he ordered the imprisonment and torture of his sister, resulting in her death. The very next day, he himself was found dead. By then, the fall of Yashnia — to either the Empire or the Elysian Church — had already become inevitable. That the Church ultimately took it... well, that's a matter for another chapter on court conspiracies.
As for Yushino's death, three theories persist: suicide brought on by madness, sudden death from chronic alcoholism, and assassination by a swordswoman named Momiji. The third is deemed the least credible — and yet, it remains the version most widely believed. This account is also said to have inspired the now-famous play Momiji: A Chronicle of Rebellion.

READ_TEXT_2000057.ContentEN:
Source: Testimony by Calem, soldier of the Narwhals
 According to Calem, his commanding officer, Falsi, retrieved this document from the central control room shortly before the explosion. 
 It is a letter of defection, pledging allegiance to the Forsakens — signed by Avar Hrodland. 
  
 Hellfire's Note: 
 Handwriting and fingerprints confirmed. 
 Still — could it be forged? 
  
  
 ※ Correspondence from Avar Hrodland 
 This letter contains specific instructions addressed to {nickname2} and Theodore, detailing acts of disruption to be carried out during the assault.
 
 
 ※ Control Panel: Central Control Room 
 Status: Data compromised due to blast damage. 
 Recovered via classified recorder — access logs from the final three days: 
 • 18 Nov: No entries
 • 19 Nov: No entries
 • 20 Nov: Avar Hrodland, {nickname2}
  
 Hellfire's Note: 
 Important.
 
 
 ※ Audio Recorder 
 Recovered from the hallway by Catto (Narwhals unit), allegedly dropped during the Forsakens' retreat. 
 At timestamp 33:17, a voice resembling Avar Hrodland is heard in conversation with an unidentified Forsakens operative. 
  
 Hellfire's Note: 
 May prove useful in establishing a timeline. Credibility remains in question.
 
  
 ※ Testimony from Calem (Narwhals unit) 
 Statements as follows:
 • "I saw Captain {nickname2} of the Griffins exit the central control room alone — there was blood all over {性别:his|her} chest."
 • "{nickname2} told us to hold position while {性别:he|she} went to check the sewers for any remaining Forsakens personnel."
 • "Two minutes later, the alarm sounded. Captain Falsi and I rushed in — found Captain Avar of the Snow Wolves lying in a pool of blood. The self-destruct sequence had already been triggered."
  
 Hellfire's Note: 
 Internal conflict?
 
 
 ※ Outstanding Questions
 • Why was the control room destroyed?
 → A cover-up to eliminate further evidence?
 
 Conflicting Accounts:
 → Testimonies from {nickname2} and Theodore directly contradict the findings above.

READ_TEXT_20602.ContentEN:
January 1st
Today, ▇▇▇▇ gave me some Phoxene shards as "pocket money." She said that back in the capital, kids get pocket money from their elders before they come of age — to spend on treats or toys.
There aren't any shops around here, so she told me to save it. Then, when there's something I really want or need, I can use it to ask for her help.
Thing is... I can't really think of anything I want.


January 2nd
I've got it! I could get {nickname} a "birthday present"! Maybe one of those "birthday cakes" kids in the capital have when they turn a year older — I read they're really tasty! They might be expensive... but if I save enough pocket money to give to ▇▇▇▇, I bet she could help me get one.
I found an old clay jar in the kitchen. It's just right for keeping my savings.


January 16th
We were playing hide-and-seek today, and {nickname} found the jar and almost opened it... I need to find a better hiding spot.
Maybe tomorrow I'll sneak into the room where ▇▇▇▇ does her alchemy work. There are loads of strange machines in there — she never lets {nickname} go near them.


January 17th
I hid my piggy bank under the <H>waterfall, right next to the alchemy chamber</>. That way, neither {nickname} nor ▇▇▇▇ will stumble across it.


...


▇▇ ▇▇
{nickname}'s birthday is coming up, and I've saved a whole box full of pocket money. It should be enough for a cake. But ▇▇▇▇ seems really busy these days. She's been staying up late a lot... Maybe it's not the right time to bother her. I guess I'll ask her next year.
With another year of saving, I can get an even bigger cake — big enough for all three of us.

READ_TEXT_20603.ContentEN:
Dear Berry,
 
 If you are reading this letter, it means you've returned after all.
 You've always been a good girl, and I trust you had your reasons for coming back.
 I've left some supplies for you, buried <H>near the airship</> — they should be enough to get you both off Purgatorio Island.
 I wish you the best on your journey. Stay safe.

READ_TEXT_20604.ContentEN:
The Goddess of Fate weaves the stars into their paths, gifting us with guiding lights that lead us towards eternal bliss.
 Yet, in our times, humanity has strayed from Her teachings. We have forsaken the bonds of love and compassion, choosing instead to arm ourselves with cold steel against our own kin. Our sacred lands have crumbled, and even Her sanctuaries have been defiled.
 Should this be the ordeal She has devised — a sombre prelude to the dawn — then to you, the destined one who will one day reach this place, I offer a blessing that transcends time.
 
 In <H>a place overlooked by Her gaze</>, I have hidden the final legacy of an age when humanity cherished love and solidarity.
 May Her tender threads of fate lead you to the true dawn.

READ_TEXT_20605.ContentEN:
Time, ever so precious, slips swiftly by,
And the changes that ensue leave us with a sigh.
In the distant corners of memory,
Beyond the emerald hills and crystal-clear waters,
Having pierced the veil of countless illusions—
I am guided by a divine light.
At the journey's end, the ultimate truth awaits.
Where trees stand barren and flowers wilt,
In lands devoid of life and hope,
Silently, a new cycle takes root.

READ_TEXT_20608.ContentEN:
Sorry, babe, there's been a hiccup at home, so I can't take you to the inner city this month as I promised. But hang tight, I'll come for you as soon as I sort things out. Trust me one more time, okay?
 As a little something to make it up to you, I've hidden some cash <H>under the grass on the left side of the pathway</> to the inner city. Don't forget to pick it up. Love you!
 
 <W>You liar! You jerk! Every time you lie to me, you just throw money at me like I'm some kind of pet you own! I'd rather starve or drop dead in the street than take another coin from you! You can rot with your filthy money for all I care!</>

READ_TEXT_20609.ContentEN:
Hey there! Are you tired of struggling to make ends meet?
Sick of breaking your back every day for a pittance, only to be treated like dirt?
Do you feel like, no matter how hard you try, you just can't catch a break?
Don't beat yourself up — it's not your fault. What you're lacking isn't skill, but a stroke of luck! All you need is the right opportunity, and you could be the next bigshot!
And guess what? It's your lucky day! Just last month, the chief engineer of our Legendary Mining Alliance unveiled a new mining marvel, ten years in the making! It is user-friendly, boasts an impressive battery life, and the cherry on top — it can automatically extract microscopic Phoxene particles — invisible to the naked eye — and turn them into solid Phoxene! With this revolutionary technology, we can breathe new life into the exhausted mines and bring Icelake's mining industry back from the brink!
 
We're on the lookout for partners right now! Opportunities like this come once in a lifetime!
Want in? Solve the puzzle below for a chance to join our elite team!
 
(Beneath the text is a simple map of the slums with a Phoxene symbol marking a spot — it appears to be near <H>a pile of old junk by the roadside rubbish bin</>.)

READ_TEXT_20610.ContentEN:
Someone found my secret stash last time...
This time, I consulted a professional, who suggested I hide it somewhere outside the city, perhaps <H>somewhere near a puddle</>.
Sure, Phoxene won't go bad in water, but what if the box gets mouldy or rots from the moisture? Then my stash would literally be "money down the drain", right?
Still, it's better than having it stolen... I'm going to give it a shot. I'll check on it next week.

READ_TEXT_20611.ContentEN:
Hey, wanna play a game?
If you can find the <H>biggest gem</> around here, I'll give you a reward!

READ_TEXT_20612.ContentEN:
<W>There are no 100 pieces of Phoxene here.</>
 
(Beneath this message, some squiggly lines attempt to outline the mine's paths. The spot marked with a red circle appears to be <H>near the mine's entrance</>.)

READ_TEXT_20613.ContentEN:
I saw it with my own eyes — blue light, shining out from <H>under that fallen pillar</>! But there's no lighting rig down there... none at all. There's definitely something weird going on!
Like... maybe some miner worked himself to death and just... never left. No wonder no one's bothered to fix it since.

READ_TEXT_20614.ContentEN:
Hello, stranger, I am an explorer.
This cavern is absolutely enchanting, like something out of a fairy tale where snow fairies might live! The massive, crystal-clear ice pillars, the rugged old roots of a withered Heaventree, and the complex terrain that twists and turns like a natural labyrinth... it'll take your breath away!
If you've made it this far, don't give up now — the scenery up there is even more spectacular! I've left a gift and some provisions for you at the <H>cavern's summit</>. Keep going — you're almost there.
May you discover the same thrill of adventure that drives me. As long as there's life in you, let the journey never end!

READ_TEXT_20615.ContentEN:
Do you remember that day we left the city and wandered along the <H>lakeside of Lamenting Lake</>, wading barefoot through the shallows?
"Look at that tree with red leaves," you said.
"They're orange," I corrected.
"I said red," you insisted.

I'd saved up a few pieces of Phoxene — I was going to trade them for a real red-leafed plant, as a gift for you.
In the end, I buried them <H>beneath that tree with the orange leaves</>.

...Yes, I still think they're orange. I'm sorry. Leaves don't turn red just because you say they are — just like you won't come back just because I keep saying you will.

Maybe, when spring comes, the Phoxene will sprout and grow — like the feelings I still carry for you. Or maybe some lucky passerby will dig them up instead.

Either way, I think that would be a good thing. You always said good things are meant to be shared. If this gift I never gave ends up helping someone else... maybe that's a kind of happy ending, too.

READ_TEXT_20616.ContentEN:
Fact: if you keep an egg somewhere warm, it hatches into a chick.
So if I leave some Phoxene somewhere warm... they'll grow into a Heaventree, right? Then I'll be rich. Forever.
I'm a genius! No, scratch that — I'm a true visionary!

And guess what? I'm on <H>furnace</> maintenance duty. Hehehe... Tomorrow, I'll sneak my Phoxene in and start the hatching...

READ_TEXT_20617.ContentEN:
Everyone's got Snowcaps all wrong! They're not dangerous — they're delicious! Simmer them just right, season with care, and boom — gourmet magic, totally safe!
But that's old news. I'm done with boring, basic mushrooms. I want more. Something wild. Something weird.
I need the king of mushrooms!

So I scoured the sewers all day, and finally, <H>near the deepest sluice gate</>, I found them — a whole cluster of brand-new mushrooms! Just the colours were enough to make my mouth water. I took a few back. Already scribbling down some ideas for the first recipe draft...

They say people used to leave offerings to the gods for good harvests. So maybe... if I leave something under this mushroom patch, the great Mushroom God of Atlasia will reward me with even tastier treasures? Didn't have much on me — just a handful of coins and a few snacks. Gave it all. Hope the Mushroom God's not too picky...

READ_TEXT_20620.ContentEN:
The fortress won't hold much longer... Don't be a fool and stay behind just because of orders. You're not even on the official roster — no one will notice if you're gone.
There are spare supplies <H>near the airship</>. Take what you need and head home!

(The bottom half of the page is unreadable from dark red splodges.)

READ_TEXT_20621.ContentEN:
Temporary Supply Pick-up Point:

<H>Beneath the control console by the viewing window on the engine room's outer perimeter.</>

READ_TEXT_20622.ContentEN:
Hey, my dear ex-teammates — let's celebrate a little festival of our own!
 
 Now, don't be hasty to shoot me down. I know the Fortress only allows Triumph Day... but surely there's no harm in a secret celebration or two, right?
 Back home, we mark the first of April with the Snowmelt Festival: trinkets hung from pine boughs as the snow retreats, gifts exchanged beneath the trees, and a fond farewell to winter as spring draws near.
 You all remember that pine in the <H>Simulated Battlefield</>, don't you? The one we riddled with bullet holes and cordite burns during drills? If you squint, I'd say those count as decorations. Next week just happens to be your training rotation — and I may have buried a little something <H>beneath that tree by the water</>. Volunteer for post-training clean-up and "accidentally" dig them up, yeah~?
 (One each — no hoarding! I'll be watching, 0^0)
 
 Even though I've been transferred to another squad, we'll always be best buds!

RESOURCE_DESC_100.ContentEN:
High-grade Phoxene derived from Phoxene Plumule.
Like precious metals, they function as common currency across Atlasia, accepted universally for trade.

RESOURCE_DESC_10001.ContentEN: A weathered old bough, snapped by fierce winds, bearing the scars of erosion that seem to have sapped it of all life.

RESOURCE_DESC_10002.ContentEN: Originating from the Hyperborean Empire, powered by Phoxichor, this apparatus generates tremendous gusts. On grand occasions, these artificial winds elevate petals, banners, and the very grandeur of the empire.

RESOURCE_DESC_10003.ContentEN: A butterfly navigating the ocean through air currents. Even in still weather, it can glide across the ocean via the currents generated from flapping its delicate wings — a small marvel with the ability to command the winds.

RESOURCE_DESC_10004.ContentEN: Originating from Huaxu, this colossal and weighty arrow defies even the fiercest storms. One can scarcely conceive who might wield such a bolt, yet its meteor-like trail across the heavens shall be indelibly etched in the memory of any witnesses.

RESOURCE_DESC_10005.ContentEN: Scales from a desert lizard, specially structured to endure scorching heat without harm. This trait adds credence to the fabled kinship between lizards and dragons, though the latter, a creature of beauty, dwells only in the realms of myth and fantasy.

RESOURCE_DESC_10006.ContentEN: The eternal flame of sanctity, a beacon signifying that Khemet endures as long as this fire burns. To the desert folk, offering fire is a gesture of everlasting friendship.

RESOURCE_DESC_10007.ContentEN: Shackles of exceptional make, forged over ages and impervious to heat, crafted to bind even the wildest of captives.

RESOURCE_DESC_10008.ContentEN: A lava stone gradually losing its heat, sheathed in a crust of cooled black rock; one can get fleet glimpses of its subsiding magma inside.

RESOURCE_DESC_10009.ContentEN: Luca's distinctive blue pearls, typically irregularly shaped when harvested from azure shells, the spherical, plump varieties being rarer. Visitors to Luca should beware of cheap, dyed imitations.

RESOURCE_DESC_1001.ContentEN: An hourglass captures not just sand, but the passage of time and cherished memories. It bears witness to a multitude of splendors and countless stories.

RESOURCE_DESC_10010.ContentEN: Highly absorbent resin, also known as a water-retaining agent, widely used in sectors like agriculture, forestry, horticulture, and construction. Although the Luca people have long utilized similar techniques for fish preservation, systematic study and mass production only started under the aegis of the Empire.

RESOURCE_DESC_10011.ContentEN: Originating from the Hyperborean Empire, this compact water purifier, standard issue for the imperial expeditionary forces, is employed to purify water on the march, safeguarding soldiers' health.

RESOURCE_DESC_10012.ContentEN: Ice harvested from the far north, exceedingly rare and clear as crystal, glinting like dew. Its process of melting and refreezing mirrors the tears on the Creator's lashes.

RESOURCE_DESC_10013.ContentEN: This apparatus channels thunderstorms beneath the earth. It is an innovation from Huaxu, a realm where the yearning for the heavens surpasses terrestrial confines.

RESOURCE_DESC_10014.ContentEN: A special mineral that fell to the ground on a stormy night, with mirror-like facets and subtle purple currents flickering within.

RESOURCE_DESC_10015.ContentEN: Wool of golden hue, reminiscent of mythical treasures. It's true that golden sheep are real, and for those with ample means, their wool can be woven into sweaters. Yet, this golden fleece is susceptible to static, making the wearer spark with movement.

RESOURCE_DESC_10016.ContentEN: Lightning ensnared by the people of Huaxu, continuing its restless dance within the bottle. This craft traces back two centuries to the priest who braved the Thunder Plains alone, anointing himself as the hunter.

RESOURCE_DESC_10017.ContentEN: A monocle that comes with various exquisite chains, favoured by Aethyrie's scholarly elite, hence dubbed "Lense of Enlightenment".

RESOURCE_DESC_10018.ContentEN: Bestowed by the Elysian Church, adorned only by those of esteemed reverence, its interlaced flowers and foliage represent devotion and allegiance, embodying a faith as pure as gold.

RESOURCE_DESC_10019.ContentEN: An Elysian Church classic, penned in verse for singing. It embodies divine teachings chronicled by patriarchs over the years, an aged print from bygone days.

RESOURCE_DESC_1002.ContentEN:
It's a bit of a mystery why a luno at the age of Snow's Granny has taken a fancy to toy hammers. Perhaps it's a smith's quirk?
Offering up toy hammers can bump you up the forging schedule. She swears it's just proper respect for the elderly, not bribery!

RESOURCE_DESC_10020.ContentEN: Scales symbolizing equality and justice, essential in the Elysian Church rituals. Should divine favour shift, the scales would tilt. Fortunately, the grace of the Great Nine has remained unchanged.

RESOURCE_DESC_10021.ContentEN: A dagger mottled with rust, its elegant engravings a testament to its owner's nobility; perhaps a personal possession of a soul fallen on ancient battlefields.

RESOURCE_DESC_10022.ContentEN: In Aethyrie, obsidian symbolizes the inspiration of the night. Each Charon scholar from Aethyrie receives this key upon graduation. The significance known only to its bearer.

RESOURCE_DESC_10023.ContentEN: The Selenism, renouncing the Great Nine to embrace the "Abyss", compiles its doctrines in a tome naturally deemed taboo. Yet, such forbidden knowledge beckons enticingly — for the curious, it unlocks gateways to a new world.

RESOURCE_DESC_10024.ContentEN: A sealed vessel originating from the Hyperborean Empire, containing the cellular essence of Filthoids. Before opening, it's an absolute black box, potentially defying expectations but also capable of bringing unforeseen wonders or horrors.

RESOURCE_DESC_1003.ContentEN: An hourglass captures not just sand, but the passage of time and cherished memories. It bears witness to a multitude of splendors and countless stories.

RESOURCE_DESC_1006.ContentEN: Even a humble blade, struck a thousand times upon the anvil, may cast off its fetters and be reborn keen.

RESOURCE_DESC_101.ContentEN:
A standard coin used across all of the Atlasia Continent.
Low in value but essential for daily transactions.

RESOURCE_DESC_10100.ContentEN: Reflecting on the long path traveled, all the memories have been woven into a tapestry of stars. The joys and sorrows contained within them have become the evidence of growth.

RESOURCE_DESC_10101.ContentEN: Only by confronting what once terrified you can you truly take control of it.

RESOURCE_DESC_10102.ContentEN: Only by confronting what once terrified you can you truly take control of it.

RESOURCE_DESC_10103.ContentEN: Only by confronting what once terrified you can you truly take control of it.

RESOURCE_DESC_10104.ContentEN: Only by confronting what once terrified you can you truly take control of it.

RESOURCE_DESC_1011101.ContentEN:
A sigil for summoning Combat Partners. It is a staff to lean on in a battle, a pact of companionship, and an oath unspoken.
Heartfelt prayers shall be answered, and the desired one shall appear by your side.

RESOURCE_DESC_102.ContentEN:
Condensed liquid globules designed to empower Demon Wedges. If Daimons are the demons roaming the mortal realm, then this material surely serves as a feast of power dedicated to them.
Developed by the Hyperborean Spathatoi Alchademy, these globules were inspired by ancient tablets unearthed by the Archaeological Association — the cryptic inscriptions on these tablets are believed to conceal mysterious powers.

RESOURCE_DESC_10200.ContentEN: A symbol of the Hyperborean Legion's great achievements and glory. Yet, individual success often correlates with collective sacrifice.

RESOURCE_DESC_10201.ContentEN: A symbol of the Hyperborean Legion's great achievements and glory. Yet, individual success often correlates with collective sacrifice.

RESOURCE_DESC_10202.ContentEN: A symbol of the Hyperborean Legion's great achievements and glory. Yet, individual success often correlates with collective sacrifice.

RESOURCE_DESC_10203.ContentEN: Only through silence and self-exploration can one achieve growth from the inside out.

RESOURCE_DESC_10204.ContentEN: Only through silence and self-exploration can one achieve growth from the inside out.

RESOURCE_DESC_10205.ContentEN: Only through silence and self-exploration can one achieve growth from the inside out.

RESOURCE_DESC_10206.ContentEN: Medicine administration is an art that heavily depends on experience. It is through the lessons learned in growth that a healer can always determine the most suitable dosage at any given time.

RESOURCE_DESC_10207.ContentEN: Medicine administration is an art that heavily depends on experience. It is through the lessons learned in growth that a healer can always determine the most suitable dosage at any given time.

RESOURCE_DESC_10208.ContentEN: Medicine administration is an art that heavily depends on experience. It is through the lessons learned in growth that a healer can always determine the most suitable dosage at any given time.

RESOURCE_DESC_10209.ContentEN: Experienced archers can hit the target even without aiming. The moment they lay their hands on strings and arrows, the memories engraved in their bodies spark.

RESOURCE_DESC_10210.ContentEN: Experienced archers can hit the target even without aiming. The moment they lay their hands on strings and arrows, the memories engraved in their bodies spark.

RESOURCE_DESC_105.ContentEN: A rare currency that can be exchanged for various rewards. Only usable during the Second Closed Beta Test.

RESOURCE_DESC_110.ContentEN: The kaleidoscope, casting a prismatic profusion of light — a sliver, caught by eyes in the darkness, unfolds countless worlds in motion.
